questions.question: Which is not an essential requirement of digestive function?
questions.explanation: The digestive system focuses on the continuous supply of nutrients, water and electrolytes, through key processes such as transit, digestion, absorption, circulation and nervous control, not on the general thermoregulation of the body.

questions.question: Which organ is primarily adapted to storage?
questions.explanation: The stomach has a specialized function in the digestive system to retain and temporarily store food before it passes to the intestine to continue the digestion and absorption processes in the body.

questions.question: What layer is between the circular and the mucosa?
questions.explanation: The intestinal wall has five main layers. From outside to inside these are: serosa, longitudinal muscle, circular muscle, submucosa and mucosa. Therefore, the submucosa is immediately below the circular muscle layer.

questions.question: How does smooth muscle work electrically?
questions.explanation: Each muscular layer of the digestive tract acts as a syncytium due to intercellular gap junctions. These junctions allow electrical signals to spread rapidly in all directions through the muscle fiber bundles.

questions.question: What are the basic types of electrical waves?
questions.explanation: The slow and almost continuous intrinsic electrical activity that runs through the membranes of smooth muscle fibers has two fundamental types of electrical waves: slow waves and spike potentials.

questions.question: What type of potential are slow waves not?
questions.explanation: Slow waves are not considered true action potentials, but rather are slow, oscillating fluctuations of the resting membrane potential whose main function is to control the appearance of intermittent spike potentials.

questions.question: What is the frequency of slow waves in the duodenum?
questions.explanation: The frequency of slow waves varies depending on the region of the digestive system. While in the gastric body it is 3 per minute, in the duodenum, this frequency reaches its maximum value, oscillating at twelve per minute.

questions.question: What cells act as electrical pacemakers?
questions.explanation: The interstitial cells of Cajal are specialized cells interspersed with the smooth muscle layers. It is believed that they act as electrical pacemakers, generating the rhythmic activity of slow waves thanks to peculiar ion channels.

questions.question: At what voltage are spike potentials generated?
questions.explanation: Spike potentials, which are true action potentials, are generated automatically only when the resting potential of the gastrointestinal smooth muscle membrane rises and reaches a value that is more positive than -40 mV.

questions.question: What ions enter through the channels during spikes?
questions.explanation: Calcium-sodium channels are responsible for action potentials in smooth muscle fibers, facilitating the entry of large amounts of calcium ions and a smaller number of sodium ions into the cell.

questions.question: What ion causes smooth muscle contraction?
questions.explanation: Contraction of gastrointestinal smooth muscle is triggered by the entry of calcium ions into the muscle fibers. These ions activate the calmodulin control mechanism, generating attractive forces between myosin and actin filaments.

questions.question: What factor causes depolarization and excitation?
questions.explanation: Depolarization of the membrane, which makes it more excitable, is caused by three main factors: distension of the muscle fiber, stimulation by released acetylcholine, and the action of specific gastrointestinal hormones.

questions.question: What factor increases negativity and reduces excitability?
questions.explanation: Hyperpolarization, which consists of making the membrane potential more negative and reducing the excitability of the muscle fiber, is induced mainly by the effect of norepinephrine or adrenaline and the stimulation of the sympathetic nerves.

questions.question: What characteristic does tonic contraction have?
options: Association to the rhythm of waves.
It is only due to spikes.
questions.explanation: Tonic contraction is a type of muscle contraction that is continuous, can last several minutes or even hours, and is not associated with the basic electrical rhythm of slow waves as is the case with rhythmic contractions.

questions.question: How many neurons does the enteric nervous system have?
questions.explanation: The enteric nervous system, which controls gastrointestinal movements and secretions, is a developed system found in the wall of the digestive tract and contains about one hundred million neurons, almost the same as the spinal cord.

questions.question: What are the two essential plexuses of the enteric system?
questions.explanation: The enteric nervous system is essentially composed of two main plexuses found in the intestinal wall: the external plexus, called myenteric or Auerbach's, and the internal plexus, known as submucosal or Meissner's.

questions.question: What is the main control of the myenteric plexus?
questions.explanation: The myenteric or Auerbach plexus, extending along the entire intestinal wall between the muscular layers, is primarily involved in the control of the motor activity of the entire digestive tract, including tonic contraction and conduction speed.

questions.question: What function does the submucosal plexus regulate?
options: The tone of the intestinal wall.
questions.explanation: Unlike the myenteric, the submucosal or Meissner plexus is primarily concerned with regulating the internal parietal function of each segment of the intestine, controlling secretion, local absorption and local contraction of the submucosal muscle.

questions.question: How does acetylcholine affect gastrointestinal activity?
questions.explanation: Acetylcholine, which is one of the main neurotransmitters secreted by enteric neurons, usually has a stimulating effect on the motor and secretory activity of the gastrointestinal system, promoting its functions.

questions.question: What is the general effect of sympathetic stimulation?
questions.explanation: Stimulation of the sympathetic nervous system, which releases norepinephrine, generally inhibits the activity of the digestive tract, both by a direct effect on smooth muscle and by an inhibitory effect on the enteric nervous system.

questions.question: What stimulates the release of cholecystokinin (CCK)?
questions.explanation: Cholecystokinin is released by the 'I' cells of the mucosa of the duodenum and jejunum in response to the presence of fat degradation products, mainly fatty acids and monoglycerides, signaling the need for bile to continue its emulsification and absorption in the small intestine.

questions.question: What is the main potent effect of CCK?
questions.explanation: CCK exerts its most powerful effect by enhancing the motility of the gallbladder, which causes the expulsion of bile into the small intestine. This bile is essential for the emulsification of fats and greatly facilitates their subsequent digestion and proper absorption.

questions.question: What effect does CCK have on the stomach?
questions.explanation: In addition to its action on the gallbladder, cholecystokinin moderately inhibits gastric contraction. This mechanism helps delay stomach emptying, ensuring the time necessary for complete and efficient digestion of fats in the upper intestine.

questions.question: What cell secretes the hormone secretin?
questions.explanation: Secretin, which was the first gastrointestinal hormone discovered, is produced and released by the 'S' cells that are located in the mucosa of the duodenum, as an immediate response to the arrival of very acidic gastric contents.

questions.question: What substance triggers the release of secretin?
questions.explanation: Secretin is released specifically in response to the arrival of acidic gastric juice into the duodenum, coming from the stomach through the pylorus. Its main objective is to initiate the neutralization of this acid to protect the intestinal mucosa from possible damage and optimize enzymatic activity.

questions.question: What is the main action of secretin?
questions.explanation: The main function of secretin is to intensely stimulate pancreatic bicarbonate secretion. This ion is vital for neutralizing the acidic environment in the small intestine, thus creating a pH suitable for the function of pancreatic digestive enzymes.

questions.question: What nutrients stimulate GIP secretion?
questions.explanation: Glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (GIP) is secreted primarily in response to the presence of fatty acids and amino acids in the lumen of the small intestine. However, to a lesser extent, it can also be stimulated by the presence of carbohydrates.

questions.question: What is an important endocrine effect of GIP?
questions.explanation: Even at low concentrations, GIP is a potent stimulator of insulin secretion. This action anticipates the arrival of glucose and other nutrients into the blood, preparing the body for their storage and immediate use after meals.

questions.question: What is the only known function of motilin?
questions.explanation: Motilin is secreted during fasting and its only well-established function is the generalized increase in gastrointestinal motility. It is responsible for initiating peristaltic cleansing waves known as interdigestive myoelectric complexes to keep the tract empty.

questions.question: How often are myoelectric complexes released?
questions.explanation: Interdigestive myoelectric complexes are motilin-stimulated waves of motility that cycle through the stomach and small intestine during fasting. These waves occur approximately every ninety minutes to remove any undigested food residue.

questions.question: What are the two types of digestive movements?
questions.explanation: The digestive tract performs two functional categories of movements: propulsion movements, which are necessary for the movement of food, and mixing movements, essential for kneading and exposing the contents to the absorption surface.

questions.question: What is the basic propulsive motion of the tube?
questions.explanation: Peristalsis is the fundamental propulsive movement in the digestive tract, characterized by a ring of contraction that forms and moves forward. This mechanism is inherent to many tubular structures containing syncytial smooth muscle in the body.

questions.question: What is the usual stimulus for peristalsis?
questions.explanation: Distension of the walls of the digestive tract is the most common stimulus that triggers peristalsis. When a considerable amount of food is concentrated at one point, the pressure on the wall activates the enteric nervous system to initiate the propulsive contractile wave.

questions.question: What does effective tube peristalsis require?
questions.explanation: Myenteric plexus activity has been shown to be essential for effective peristalsis. Portions of the digestive tract with congenital absence of this plexus or its pharmacological paralysis result in extremely weak or completely absent peristalsis.

questions.question: How is peristalsis directed according to the 'law of the intestine'?
questions.explanation: The 'law of the intestine' describes that peristaltic waves, although they could be directed in any direction, peristalsis in the oral direction is turned off, while that directed towards the anus (anal direction) continues, a phenomenon facilitated by the polarization of the myenteric plexus.

questions.question: What does the splanchnic circulation system include?
questions.explanation: The splanchnic circulation is an extensive vascular system formed by blood flow from the digestive tract itself, in addition to flow from the spleen, pancreas, and liver. It is designed to deliver nutrients to the liver before systemic circulation.

questions.question: What vein carries blood from the intestine to the liver?
questions.explanation: All blood that passes through the intestine, spleen, and pancreas immediately flows to the liver through the portal vein. This design ensures that absorbed nutrients and bacteria are filtered by the liver before entering the general circulation.

questions.question: How are most intestinal fats absorbed?
questions.explanation: Unlike carbohydrates and proteins, almost all fats that are absorbed in the intestine do not pass into the portal blood. Instead, they go to the intestinal lymphatics, from where they reach the general bloodstream through the thoracic duct, bypassing the liver.

questions.question: What is gastrointestinal blood flow directly proportional to?
options: To the degree of local activity
questions.explanation: The blood flow of each region of the digestive tract and its layers is directly proportional to its activity. During active nutrient absorption, for example, blood flow to the villi and submucosa can increase up to eight-fold to meet the increased metabolic demand.

questions.question: What initial effect does sympathetic stimulation have on flow?
questions.explanation: Sympathetic stimulation has a direct and generalized effect of intense vasoconstriction on the arterioles of the digestive tract. This mechanism is crucial, as it allows blood flow to be temporarily diverted from the splanchnic area to vital organs such as the brain and heart during emergency situations or intense exercise.

questions.question: What cranial nerve innervates the muscles of mastication?
questions.explanation: The masticatory muscles receive innervation mainly from the motor branches of the V cranial nerve, also known as the trigeminal nerve, which is essential for the control of jaw movements and the grinding of food.

questions.question: What is the occlusion force on molars?
questions.explanation: The joint action of the maxillary muscles allows the dental occlusion force to reach significant values, reaching up to 100 kilograms in the posterior teeth, which demonstrates its great crushing capacity.

questions.question: What breaks down chewing in raw fruits and vegetables?
questions.explanation: Chewing is of particular importance for fruits and vegetables due to their high cellulose content. The process ruptures these indigestible membranes to expose and allow digestion of the nutrients contained within.

questions.question: How many phases does the swallowing process have?
questions.explanation: The act of swallowing or swallowing is organized into three successive phases to guarantee the safe passage of food: an initial voluntary phase, a pharyngeal phase and an esophageal phase, both of which are involuntary.

questions.question: What action initiates the voluntary phase of swallowing?
questions.explanation: The beginning of swallowing occurs voluntarily by pressing the tongue up and back against the palate, thus moving the bolus toward the pharynx, where the reflex process begins.

questions.question: Where is the swallowing center located?
questions.explanation: The swallowing center is located in the reticular substance, encompassing the medulla oblongata and the lower portion of the pons. This area is responsible for automatically coordinating the ordered sequence of swallowing reflexes.

questions.question: What structure closes the entrance to the nasal passages?
questions.explanation: During the pharyngeal phase, the soft palate is automatically elevated. This action seals the choanae, an essential protective mechanism that prevents the bolus or liquids from refluxing into the nasal cavities.

questions.question: What prevents food from entering the trachea?
questions.explanation: The forced approximation of the vocal cords is the primary mechanism to prevent aspiration, since they close with great force, preventing the passage of food to the larynx and, consequently, to the trachea.

questions.question: What prevents air from entering the esophagus?
questions.explanation: The pharyngoesophageal sphincter, also known as the upper esophageal sphincter, remains tonically contracted between acts of swallowing, fulfilling the vital function of preventing the involuntary entry of atmospheric air into the esophagus.

questions.question: What does the swallowing center do with breathing?
questions.explanation: The swallowing center has the ability to directly inhibit the respiratory center in the medulla. This causes a momentary interruption of breathing while the act of swallowing is performed, which lasts less than six seconds.

questions.question: How many types of peristaltic movements are there in the esophagus?
questions.explanation: The esophagus develops two types of peristaltic movements to propel the bolus: primary peristalsis, which is the initial wave of the pharynx, and secondary peristalsis, which corrects if the first does not completely empty the esophagus.

questions.question: How long does it take for the primary peristaltic wave to reach the stomach?
questions.explanation: The primary peristaltic wave is a continuation of the wave that originates in the pharynx and propagates along the esophagus, taking an average of 8 to 10 seconds to travel the entire length until reaching the stomach.

questions.question: What causes unsatisfactory relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter?
questions.explanation: Failure or unsatisfactory relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter is the cause of a clinical condition known as achalasia, which severely hinders the passage of food from the esophagus to the gastric cavity.

questions.question: What is the name of the semi-liquid porridge resulting from gastric mixture?
questions.explanation: After food is intensely mixed with the acidic and enzymatic secretions of the stomach, the resulting cloudy, semi-liquid mass, which travels to the intestine, is technically called chyme.

questions.question: What is the main mechanism of gastric mixing?
questions.explanation: Retropulsion is the most effective mixing mechanism, where peristaltic waves compress the contents near the pylorus. Because the opening is small, most of the contents are forced back into the gastric body.

questions.question: What gastric hormone stimulates the pyloric pump?
questions.explanation: Gastrin is a hormone released by the G cells of the antrum that has a moderate stimulating effect on motor functions. It is particularly important because it enhances the activity of the pyloric pump, facilitating emptying.

questions.question: What duodenal pH level strongly activates the inhibitory reflex?
questions.explanation: The enterogastric nervous reflexes are extremely sensitive to acidity, activating vigorously whenever the pH of the chyme in the duodenum drops below 3.5 to 4.0, stopping the arrival of more acid.

questions.question: What is the main stimulus for CCK release?
questions.explanation: Fats entering the duodenum are the most potent stimulus for the release of Cholecystokinin (CCK) from the jejunal epithelium. This hormone plays a regulatory role by slowing gastric motility to allow slow digestion of fats.

questions.question: How does Cholecystokinin (CCK) affect gastric emptying?
questions.explanation: Cholecystokinin acts as an inhibitor by blocking the enhancement of gastric motility that gastrin could induce. Its effect is to ensure that the small intestine does not receive more chyme than it can process effectively.

questions.question: What type of contractions produce segmentation in the intestine?
questions.explanation: Mixture contractions are localized concentric contractions that are spaced at intervals and last no more than a minute. These are responsible for the 'segmentation' of the intestine, which has the appearance of a string of sausages.

questions.question: What is the maximum frequency of segmentation contractions in the duodenum and proximal jejunum?
questions.explanation: The maximum frequency of segmentation contractions in the duodenum and proximal jejunum does not exceed twelve per minute, although this level is only reached under conditions of extreme stimulation, which sets the pace of motor activity in this portion of the small intestine.

questions.question: What is the net forward movement of chyme along the small intestine?
questions.explanation: Although individual peristaltic waves move at a higher speed, the net and effective movement of chyme along the small intestine is quite slow, averaging one centimeter per minute, which ensures the time necessary for absorption.

questions.question: Which of these hormones inhibits small intestine motility?
questions.explanation: Secretin is a peptide hormone released in response to duodenal acidity, and is known to have an inhibitory effect on small intestinal motility, unlike gastrin or motilin, which typically stimulate it during food processing.

questions.question: What reflex increases peristalsis after stomach distension?
questions.explanation: The gastroenteric reflex originates from distention of the stomach and significantly increases peristaltic activity along the entire wall of the small intestine, being mediated mainly by the myenteric nerve plexus of the intestinal wall.

questions.question: What is the main function of intestinal villi contractions?
questions.explanation: Contractions of the villi, caused by muscle fibers of the muscularis mucosae, cause intermittent shortening and elongation that helps milk the contents of the central chyliferae, thus facilitating the flow of lymph into the lymphatic system.

questions.question: What prevents the ileocecal valve from protruding into the cecum?
questions.explanation: The main function of the ileocecal valve, thanks to its protruding leaflets, is to prevent the fecal contents of the cecum and colon from returning towards the ileum, resisting considerable reverse pressures to maintain the unidirectionality of intestinal transit.

questions.question: What is the dominant function of the proximal half of the colon?
questions.explanation: The proximal half of the colon is specialized in the absorption of water and electrolytes from chyme, its main function being the transformation of this semi-liquid material into a more solid fecal mass for subsequent storage and evacuation.

questions.question: What structures contract to form the haustra in the colon?
questions.explanation: Haustras are formed by the combined contraction of the circular muscle, which forms constrictions, and the three longitudinal bands of muscle, called taenia colic, causing the intestine to protrude into unstimulated areas, slowly mixing and pushing out fecal contents.

questions.question: What is the typical frequency of mass movements in the colon?
options: One to three times a day
questions.explanation: Dough movements, which are the main type of propulsive movement in the colon, are infrequent, typically occurring one to three times a day, most frequently within fifteen minutes after breakfast.

questions.question: What reflexes facilitate the initiation of mass movements after eating?
questions.explanation: Mass movements are facilitated by the gastrocolic reflex and the duodenocolic reflex, which are initiated by distension of the stomach and duodenum, respectively, as part of an autonomic nervous system response to food processing.

questions.question: What type of muscle makes up the internal anal sphincter?
questions.explanation: The internal anal sphincter is a thickening of the circular smooth muscle layer that is located immediately anterior to the anus, and its contraction is tonic and automatic, that is, it is not under the direct conscious control of the person.

questions.question: Which nerve consciously controls the external anal sphincter?
questions.explanation: The external anal sphincter is composed of voluntary striated muscle and is controlled by somatic nerve fibers of the pudendal nerve, allowing the closure of this sphincter to be kept under conscious or at least subconscious voluntary control.

questions.question: Which defecation reflex is usually considered weak on its own?
questions.explanation: The intrinsic defecation reflex, mediated solely by the enteric nervous system of the rectal wall, is usually relatively weak and must be reinforced by the much more powerful parasympathetic reflex to cause effective evacuation.

questions.question: What intense phenomenon can be caused by irritation of the intestinal mucosa?
questions.explanation: The peristaltic rush is a rapid and powerful peristalsis response that travels long distances in the small intestine in a few minutes, being caused by intense irritation of the mucosa, as in severe cases of infectious diarrhea, to eliminate the irritating content.

questions.question: What happens to peristalsis of the ileum when the cecum is distended?
questions.explanation: When the cecum is distended, local reflexes enhance contraction of the ileocecal sphincter and, at the same time, ileal peristalsis is inhibited, which together function as a feedback mechanism to delay the passage of more chyme from the ileum to the large intestine.

questions.question: How many hours does it take for chyme to reach the ileocecal valve from the pylorus?
questions.explanation: Due to the slowness of the net forward movement of the chyme, the time required for the digested material to travel the entire length of the small intestine, from the pylorus to the ileocecal valve, is estimated to be in the range of three to five hours.

questions.question: What is the maximum frequency of segmentation contractions in the terminal ileum?
questions.explanation: In the terminal ileum, which is the distal portion of the small intestine, the maximum frequency of the basic electrical rhythm that governs segmentation contractions is lower than in the proximal portions, usually ranging between eight and nine contractions per minute.

questions.question: What reflex is caused by irritation of the peritoneum?
questions.explanation: The peritoneumintestinal reflex is an autonomic reflex that is activated by irritation of the peritoneum, resulting in a strong inhibition of the excitatory enteric nerves, which can lead to intestinal paralysis, as is often observed in patients suffering from peritonitis.

questions.question: What nervous component is essential for effective segmentation contractions?
questions.explanation: Although slow waves of smooth muscle are what cause segmentation contractions, they are not effective without a constant background excitation that is provided specifically by the myenteric nerve plexus, which increases their intensity.

questions.question: Which of these pairs are hormones that stimulate intestinal motility?
questions.explanation: Cholecystokinin (CCK) and motilin, along with gastrin, insulin and serotonin, are hormones that are released during the food processing phases and have a known stimulating effect on the general motility of the small intestine.

questions.question: What type of single-celled glands lubricate the digestive epithelium?
questions.explanation: Mucous cells, also known as goblet cells due to their appearance, are single-celled glands located on the surface of the digestive epithelium, specialized in the expulsion of mucus, which acts as a protective lubricant against excoriation and chemical damage to the intestinal wall.

questions.question: What cellular structure synthesizes the secreted organic substances?
questions.explanation: The synthesis of organic substances secreted by glandular cells takes place almost exclusively in the endoplasmic reticulum, and is then completed and packaged in the Golgi apparatus, where the materials are modified, concentrated and stored in secretory vesicles.

questions.question: What is the source of energy for glandular secretion?
questions.explanation: The energy necessary for the synthesis of organic substances and for the active transport processes in secretion is supplied by the adenosine triphosphate (ATP) molecule, which is produced by the oxidative energy process that takes place in the mitochondria.

questions.question: Which ion causes fusion of vesicles and expulsion of contents?
questions.explanation: Nervous or hormonal signals cause an increase in the permeability of the cell membrane to calcium ions (Ca}^{2+), and the entry of this ion into the cell triggers the fusion of the secretory vesicles with the apical cell membrane to empty their contents to the outside, a process known as exocytosis.

questions.question: What deep structures are found in the small intestine?
questions.explanation: The crypts of Lieberkühn are deep invaginations of the intestinal epithelium into the submucosa, typical of the small intestine, and house specialized secretory cells that produce digestive juices, being crucial in the process of intestinal secretion.

questions.question: What does NOT activate the enteric nervous system for secretion?
questions.explanation: The enteric nervous system of the intestinal wall is activated by three main types of stimuli: tactile stimulation, chemical irritation and distension of the intestinal wall, which triggers reflexes that excite the secretion of the digestive glands in that area and adjacent.

questions.question: What nerves innervate the proximal portion of the digestive tract?
questions.explanation: Parasympathetic stimulation, responsible for increasing the speed of glandular secretion, occurs especially in the glands of the proximal part of the digestive tract, which are innervated by the glossopharyngeal and vagus parasympathetic nerves, covering structures such as the salivary glands and the pancreas.

questions.question: What is a double effect of sympathetic stimulation?
questions.explanation: Sympathetic stimulation induces constriction of the blood vessels supplying the glands, causing a decrease in blood flow, which can reduce, sometimes greatly, a copious glandular secretion that was already being produced by parasympathetic or hormonal stimulation.

questions.question: What chemical nature are most gastrointestinal hormones?
questions.explanation: Gastrointestinal hormones that regulate the volume and character of secretions, such as gastrin, are polypeptides or derivatives thereof, which are released from the gastrointestinal mucosa into the blood in response to the presence of food in the intestinal or stomach lumen.

questions.question: What is digestive mucus primarily composed of?
questions.explanation: Mucus is a dense secretion composed mainly of water, electrolytes and a mixture of several glycoproteins, which are large polysaccharides attached to much smaller amounts of proteins, which gives it its lubricating and protective properties of the gastrointestinal wall.

questions.question: What property of mucus prevents chemical damage to the epithelium?
questions.explanation: Mucus glycoproteins have amphoteric properties, which means that they can buffer small amounts of acids or alkalis, in addition to containing bicarbonate ions (HCO}_3^{-) that specifically neutralize acids, thus protecting the gastroesophageal and stomach mucosa.

questions.question: Which of these salivary glands only secretes mucus?
questions.explanation: The tiny oral glands, in contrast to the larger glands (parotid, submandibular and sublingual), are specialized in the exclusive secretion of mucus, fulfilling a localized lubrication and protection function in the oral cavity.

questions.question: What serous enzyme in saliva digests starches?
questions.explanation: Saliva contains a serous secretion rich in ptyalin, which is an alpha-amylase, a digestive enzyme whose main function is to begin the hydrolysis of starches in the mouth, being a key component of the beginning of the digestive process.

questions.question: Which ion is several times smaller in saliva than in plasma?
questions.explanation: During the passage of primary secretion through the salivary ducts, an active reabsorption of sodium ions (Na}^{+) occurs that greatly reduces their concentration in the final saliva, being several times lower than their plasma concentration, a process that also facilitates the passive reabsorption of chloride.

questions.question: What process occurs with K}^{+ along the salivary duct?
questions.explanation: The process that occurs along the salivary duct is the active secretion of potassium ions (K}^+), which are exchanged for sodium ions (Na^{+) that are actively reabsorbed, resulting in a salivary potassium concentration that is up to seven times greater than that of plasma under resting conditions.

questions.question: What factor in saliva destroys oral bacteria?
questions.explanation: Saliva contains several bacteria-destroying factors, the most important being thiocyanate ions and several proteolytic enzymes such as lysozyme, which attack pathogens and help eliminate the metabolic substrate used by oral flora, thus maintaining oral hygiene.

questions.question: What is the main function of esophageal secretions?
questions.explanation: Esophageal secretions, which are mucous in nature, have the main function of providing the necessary lubrication to facilitate the sliding of food along the esophagus during swallowing, in addition to protecting the lower portion from the reflux of acidic gastric juices.

questions.question: Which gastric glands secrete the hormone gastrin?
questions.explanation: The pyloric glands, which are located in the gastric antrum, the distal portion of the stomach, have as their main function the secretion of mucus to protect the mucosa, and are also responsible for producing and releasing the important hormone gastrin.

questions.question: Which gastric cell secretes intrinsic factor?
questions.explanation: Parietal cells, also called oxyntic cells, are found in the oxyntic glands of the body and gastric fundus and are responsible for secreting both hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor, which is vital for the correct absorption of vitamin B}_12 in the small intestine.

questions.question: What is the driving force for the secretion of hydrochloric acid?
questions.explanation: The main driving force for the secretion of hydrochloric acid (HCl) by parietal cells is the hydrogen-potassium pump (H}^+-K^{+-ATPase), an active transport process that exchanges hydrogen ions (H}^+) for potassium ions (K^{+) towards the canaliculi, requiring a large amount of energy to achieve extreme acidity.

questions.question: What enzyme catalyzes the formation of bicarbonate in the parietal cell?
questions.explanation: This enzyme facilitates the rapid combination of carbon dioxide and water to form carbonic acid, which quickly dissociates into bicarbonate and H^+ ions, initiating the process of secretion of hydrochloric acid.

questions.question: What is the approximate concentration of H}^{+ in the lumen of the canaliculus?
questions.explanation: The parietal cell actively transports H}^{+ to the canaliculi through the H^+/K^+/ATPase pump, which allows reaching a very high concentration of hydrogen ions, essential for digestive function.

questions.question: What factor protects the gastric wall from acid autodigestion?
questions.explanation: This viscous gel layer, secreted by superficial mucosal cells, has an alkaline nature that neutralizes hydrochloric acid before it can permanently damage the underlying gastric wall.

questions.question: Which of the following chemicals can damage the gastric barrier?
questions.explanation: Excessive consumption of toxic substances such as acetylsalicylic acid or alcohol compromises the integrity of this protective barrier, thus facilitating the retrofiltration of acid and causing serious damage to the stomach mucosa.

questions.question: What factor stimulates the secretion of pepsinogen by peptic cells?
questions.explanation: Acetylcholine, released by parasympathetic stimulation (vagus nerve), is the main factor that excites the secretion of pepsinogen by peptic cells, in addition to having a stimulating effect on parietal and mucosal cells.

questions.question: What molecule activates pepsinogen to become pepsin?
questions.explanation: Once pepsinogen comes into contact with hydrochloric acid in the stomach, it undergoes a molecular cleavage process that converts it into the active enzyme pepsin, essential for the initial digestion of proteins.

questions.question: What is the optimal pH for the proteolytic activity of pepsin?
questions.explanation: Pepsin is a proteolytic enzyme that requires a very acidic environment to exert its digestive activity with maximum efficiency, so it loses much of its action when the pH rises to levels greater than 5.0.

questions.question: What substance secreted by parietal cells is vital for the absorption of B_12?
questions.explanation: This substance is essential for the absorption of vitamin B_12 in the ileum, and its absence, caused by the destruction of parietal cells, causes a form of anemia known as pernicious.

questions.question: What glands in the stomach secrete gastrin?
questions.explanation: G cells, which produce the hormone gastrin, are found almost exclusively in the pyloric glands of the distal portion of the stomach, from where they control and stimulate gastric secretion.

questions.question: What cells release histamine in direct contact with parietal cells?
questions.explanation: These cells are located in the deep area of ​​the gastric glands and their main function is to secrete histamine, the amount of which is directly proportional to the rate of stimulation of hydrochloric acid by the parietal cells.

questions.question: What hormone stimulates ECL cells to secrete histamine?
questions.explanation: Gastrin, released in response to food proteins, travels through the blood and directly stimulates enterochromaffin-like cells (ECLs) to release histamine, a potent stimulator of acid secretion.

questions.question: Which of the two forms of gastrin is the most abundant?
questions.explanation: Gastrin is a polypeptide secreted in two main forms, G-34 (larger) and G-17 (smaller), the latter being the form found in the highest concentration in the human body.

questions.question: What percentage of total gastric secretion does the cephalic phase provide?
questions.explanation: This phase, which occurs due to sensory stimuli such as the sight, smell or taste of food, is responsible for approximately one third of the gastric secretion associated with the ingestion of a meal.

questions.question: What percentage of total gastric secretion is contributed by the gastric phase?
questions.explanation: This phase is the most important and occurs when food has already entered the stomach, exciting local nervous reflexes, vagal reflexes and the gastrin-histamine mechanism, constituting the majority of the total secretion.

questions.question: Which of the following is a hormone that inhibits gastric secretion?
questions.explanation: Secretin is released by the intestinal mucosa in response to acidic chyme in the duodenum, and initiates the reverse enterogastric reflex, inhibiting gastric secretion to protect the small intestinal mucosa.

questions.question: Which of the following pancreatic enzymes is essential for digesting neutral fats?
questions.explanation: Pancreatic lipase is one of the main enzymes for the digestion of fats, being responsible for hydrolyzing neutral fats into free fatty acids and monoglycerides, thus facilitating their subsequent absorption.

questions.question: What intestinal enzyme activates trypsinogen to trypsin?
questions.explanation: This enzyme is secreted by the intestinal mucosa when chyme comes into contact with it, being crucial because it converts inactive trypsinogen into active trypsin, initiating the activation of other proteolytic enzymes.

questions.question: What substance prevents self-digestion of the pancreas by its enzymes?
questions.explanation: This substance is formed in the cytoplasm of glandular cells and is secreted to prevent the activation of trypsinogen and other proteolytic enzymes within the pancreatic ducts and acini, preventing acute pancreatitis.

questions.question: What cells primarily secrete bicarbonate ions in the pancreas?
questions.explanation: Although enzymes are secreted in the acini, bicarbonate ions and water are mainly secreted by these cells along the ducts and ducts, with the aim of neutralizing the acid that reaches the duodenum.

questions.question: What hormone stimulates the copious secretion of aqueous bicarbonate solution?
questions.explanation: This hormone is released by the duodenal mucosa in large quantities when the pH of the chyme falls below 4.5, acting on the pancreatic ductal cells to release an aqueous and alkaline solution that neutralizes the acid.

questions.question: What is not the main function of bile?
questions.explanation: Bile plays a fundamental role in the digestion and absorption of fats through emulsification and the formation of micelles. It also serves as an excretion pathway for products such as bilirubin and excess cholesterol, but it lacks enzymes to hydrolyze carbohydrates, therefore, it is not its main function.

questions.question: Waste product excreted in bile?
questions.explanation: Bilirubin is the end product of the destruction of hemoglobin and, along with excess cholesterol, is one of the main waste products that the liver actively excretes from the blood into the intestine through bile.

questions.question: Who secretes the initial portion of bile?
questions.explanation: The initial portion of bile, which contains most of the bile acids, cholesterol and other organic components, is secreted directly by hepatocytes, which are the primary functional cells of liver tissue.

questions.question: Maximum concentration reached by bile?
questions.explanation: The gallbladder mucosa absorbs water and electrolytes, which concentrates the organic components of bile. Although the average concentration is five times, it can reach a maximum of up to twenty times its original concentration in extreme situations.

questions.question: What is key in vesicular absorption?
questions.explanation: The concentration of bile in the gallbladder is achieved primarily by the active transport of sodium ions across its epithelium, generating an osmotic gradient that then secondarily draws water and other small electrolytes out.

questions.question: Which solute is secreted in the greatest quantity?
questions.explanation: Bile salts are by far the largest solute secreted in bile. They represent approximately half of the total solutes, being crucial for the emulsification and absorption of fats in the small intestine.

questions.question: Most powerful hormone for gallbladder contraction?
questions.explanation: Cholecystokinin (CCK) is the main and most potent hormonal stimulus for emptying the gallbladder, causing rhythmic contractions of its wall and simultaneous relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi to allow the passage of bile.

questions.question: What stimulates CCK release?
questions.explanation: Cholecystokinin (CCK) is secreted from the cells of the duodenal mucosa into the blood mainly in response to the arrival of fatty foods in the duodenum, since CCK is necessary for the digestion of these fats.

questions.question: What is the precursor of bile salts?
questions.explanation: Bile salts are synthesized by hepatocytes from cholesterol, which can be obtained from the diet or synthesized by the liver itself. Cholesterol is converted into cholic and chenodeoxycholic acids, which are then conjugated to form bile salts.

questions.question: What is the detergent function called?
questions.explanation: The detergent action of bile salts on large fat particles in the intestine, resulting in their fragmentation into multiple tiny particles, is called the emulsifying function and is key to the subsequent attack by lipases.

questions.question: What are semisoluble complexes called?
questions.explanation: Bile salts physically combine with the final products of lipid digestion to form micelles, which are semi-soluble ultramicroscopic complexes that facilitate the transport of lipids to the intestinal mucosa for subsequent absorption.

questions.question: Percentage of bile salts reabsorbed?
questions.explanation: Approximately 94% of bile salts are reabsorbed from the small intestine, mostly by active transport in the distal ileum, to return to the liver and be secreted again, which is known as the enterohepatic circulation.

questions.question: What is the name of salt recirculation?
questions.explanation: The recirculation of bile salts, which involves their reabsorption in the small intestine, passage into the portal blood, uptake by the liver and new excretion into the bile, is called enterohepatic circulation.

questions.question: Which bile component increases secretin?
questions.explanation: The hormone secretin increases bile secretion by primarily stimulating the epithelial cells of the bile ducts to secrete an aqueous solution with large amounts of sodium and bicarbonate ions, which helps neutralize acid in the duodenum.

questions.question: Contributing factor to gallstones?
questions.explanation: The formation of cholesterol gallstones occurs mainly when there is an excess of cholesterol in the bile in relation to the amounts of bile salts and lecithin, causing cholesterol, which is insoluble in pure water, to precipitate and form crystals.

questions.question: Where are Brunner's glands located?
questions.explanation: Brunner's glands are compound mucous glands that are specifically located in the wall of the duodenum, especially in its first centimeters, playing a protective role against the acid that arrives from the stomach.

questions.question: Main function of Brunner's mucus?
questions.explanation: The alkaline mucus secreted by the Brunner's glands contains bicarbonate ions and its primary function is to protect the wall of the duodenal mucosa against erosion and digestion caused by the very acidic gastric juice that enters the duodenum.

questions.question: What do crypt enterocytes secrete?
questions.explanation: The enterocytes located in the crypts of Lieberkühn daily secrete large quantities of a watery intestinal fluid that is almost entirely pure extracellular fluid, which serves as a vehicle for the absorption of nutrients in the adjacent villi.

questions.question: What type of enzymes do enterocytes have?
questions.explanation: The enterocytes that cover the villi contain in their brush border key digestive enzymes such as several peptidases to fractionate peptides and four types of disaccharidases (sucrase, maltase, isomaltase and lactase) to break down disaccharides into monosaccharides ready for absorption.

questions.question: How long is the life cycle of an enterocyte?
questions.explanation: The intestinal epithelium is continually renewed thanks to the mitotic division of cells in the crypts of Lieberkühn. The life cycle of epithelial cells, from their birth to their detachment at the tip of the villus, is remarkably rapid, lasting approximately five days.

questions.question: What basic process is the same for the digestion of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins?
questions.explanation: Hydrolysis is the fundamental process of chemical digestion of the main foods (carbohydrates, fats and proteins). It consists of the addition of a water molecule, separating the linked components by condensation. What changes between food types are the specific digestive enzymes required for each hydrolysis reaction.

questions.question: Which end product accounts for more than 80% of carbohydrate digestion?
questions.explanation: In the usual diet, which contains a high percentage of starches, glucose is the most abundant monosaccharide, representing more than 80% of the final product of carbohydrate digestion. Galactose and fructose usually contribute less than 10% each.

questions.question: What salivary enzyme initiates the digestion of starch in the mouth?
questions.explanation: Ptyalin is an alpha-amylase secreted primarily by the parotid gland, which is found in saliva. This enzyme begins the hydrolysis of starch, converting it into maltose and small glucose polymers before its action is blocked by stomach acid.

questions.question: What is the main function of pepsin in the stomach?
questions.explanation: An essential characteristic of pepsin is its ability to digest protein collagen, an important component of the intercellular connective tissue of meats. Its action is crucial so that subsequent proteolytic enzymes can penetrate and act on meat proteins.

questions.question: What substances are formed by the digestion of triglycerides?
questions.explanation: Pancreatic lipase, the most important enzyme for triglyceride digestion, breaks down most of these dietary fats to free fatty acids and 2-monoglycerides. This hydrolysis is essential for its subsequent intestinal absorption.

questions.question: Where does most protein digestion take place?
questions.explanation: Most protein digestion takes place in the proximal part of the small intestine, specifically in the duodenum and jejunum, mainly by the action of potent proteolytic enzymes of pancreatic secretion, such as trypsin and chymotrypsin.

questions.question: What process initiates the digestion of fats for enzymes?
questions.explanation: The first step to effective fat digestion is emulsification. This process reduces the size of the fat globules, which drastically increases the contact surface so that lipases, which are water-soluble, can act efficiently on them.

questions.question: What intestinal enzymes break down disaccharides into monosaccharides?
questions.explanation: The enterocytes that line the brush border of the intestinal villi contain enzymes such as lactase, sucrase, maltase, and alpha-dextrinase. These enzymes break down disaccharides and small polymers of glucose into their constituent monosaccharides (glucose, galactose, fructose).

questions.question: What molecule results from the hydrolysis of lactose?
questions.explanation: Lactose, a disaccharide present in milk, is fractionated by the enzyme lactase (present in the intestinal epithelium) through hydrolysis, resulting in a molecule of galactose and another molecule of glucose, which are easily absorbable monosaccharides.

questions.question: Which component of fat lacks fatty acids?
questions.explanation: Cholesterol is a sterol that, unlike triglycerides, phospholipids and cholesterol esters, lacks fatty acids in its molecular structure. However, it is classified as part of fats in dietary terms due to its similar origin and metabolism.

questions.question: What polymers are the intermediate product of starch digestion?
questions.explanation: Amylolytic enzymes (salivary ptyalin and pancreatic alpha-amylase) hydrolyze starch, converting it mainly to the disaccharide maltose and other small glucose polymers, made up of 3 to 9 glucose molecules. These are subsequently degraded by enzymes in the intestine.

questions.question: What is cellulose for human digestion?
questions.explanation: Cellulose is a carbohydrate that is ingested in the diet. However, the human digestive tract lacks the necessary enzymes to hydrolyze it, so it cannot be digested or absorbed, being considered a non-nutritive fiber for humans.

questions.question: What major pancreatic enzymes attack partially digested proteins?
questions.explanation: Once the products of stomach protein digestion (proteose, peptones, polypeptides) reach the small intestine, they are attacked by the powerful pancreatic proteolytic enzymes, the main ones being trypsin and chymotrypsin, which cleave the protein molecules into smaller polypeptides.

questions.question: What is the function of pancreatic carboxypolypeptidase?
options: Release amino acids from the carboxyl
questions.explanation: Carboxypolypeptidase is a pancreatic enzyme that acts on the carboxyl terminus of polypeptides. Its specific function is to release individual amino acids one by one from the polypeptide chain resulting from the action of trypsin and chymotrypsin.

questions.question: How much fluid passes into the colon from the ileum daily?
questions.explanation: Of a total of 8 to 9 liters of fluid that enters the small intestine (ingested fluid plus gastrointestinal secretions), most of it is absorbed there. There are only approximately 1.5 liters per day that pass through the ileocecal valve to the colon, which absorbs most of the remainder.

questions.question: What anatomical structures increase the intestinal absorption area 10 times?
questions.explanation: Villi are small mucosal projections that extend along the surface of the small intestine. Its presence is responsible for increasing the absorption area approximately 10 times. In addition, each villus is covered by enterocytes with microvilli that further increase the surface area.

questions.question: What cellular structure contains the final peptidases of protein digestion?
questions.explanation: The brush border cell membrane of the microvilli of enterocytes (intestinal cells) contains multiple peptidases, such as aminopolypeptidase and dipeptidases. These perform the final step of digestion of large polypeptides, tripeptides and dipeptides into amino acids.

questions.question: Which component of bile is crucial for the emulsification of fats?
questions.explanation: Bile, produced by the liver, contains large amounts of bile salts and the phospholipid lecithin. Both substances are essential for the fat emulsification process, with lecithin being particularly useful for fragmenting fat globules by reducing surface tension.

questions.question: What structure do bile salts form to transport digested fats?
questions.explanation: Bile salts form micelles in aqueous solution, which are small spherical globules that solubilize and transport the end products of fat digestion, such as 2-monoglycerides and free fatty acids, to the brush border of intestinal epithelial cells for absorption.

questions.question: What percentage of total starches are hydrolyzed in the mouth when swallowed?
questions.explanation: Although salivary ptyalin begins to hydrolyze starch, food remains in the mouth for a very short time. For this reason, at the time of swallowing, no more than 5% of all starches ingested are already hydrolyzed. Digestion continues in the stomach and is completed in the intestine.

questions.question: What structure captures lymph in the villi?
questions.explanation: The chyliferous lymphatic is the central lymphatic vessel within the intestinal villus. Its main function is the absorption and transport of digested fats, in the form of chylomicrons, to the lymphatic system and, finally, to the systemic circulation. It is essential for lipid absorption.

questions.question: How much does the brush edge increase the absorption surface?
questions.explanation: The brush border is composed of thousands of microvilli that protrude from each epithelial cell. This microscopic increase in surface area exposed to intestinal matter increases absorption capacity by at least 20 times, dramatically improving digestive efficiency.

questions.question: What is the total absorptive surface area of ​​the small intestine?
questions.explanation: The combination of Kerckring folds, villi, and microvilli increases the absorptive surface area of ​​the mucosa by almost 1,000 times, resulting in a total surface area of ​​250 m}^2 or more, comparable to that of a tennis court, to maximize nutrient absorption.

questions.question: How is water transported through the intestinal membrane?
questions.explanation: Water is transported entirely across the intestinal membrane by simple diffusion, a passive process that obeys the usual laws of osmosis. It follows the osmotic gradient created by the active transport of solutes, primarily sodium, out of the cell into the paracellular space.

questions.question: Where is the active sodium pump located in the enterocyte?
questions.explanation: The sodium-potassium pump (Na}^+-K}^+-ATPase) is located in the basal and lateral membranes of epithelial cells. This pump actively transports sodium out of the cell and into the paracellular space, creating a low concentration gradient within the cytoplasm, which in turn drives the cotransport of sodium and other nutrients.

questions.question: What hormone enhances the absorption of sodium and intestinal water?
questions.explanation: Aldosterone is secreted by the adrenal cortex in large quantities in situations of dehydration. This hormone stimulates the transport mechanisms and enzymes involved in the absorption of sodium by the intestinal epithelium, which secondarily increases the absorption of water and chloride to preserve volume.

questions.question: How is the bicarbonate ion absorbed in the duodenum and jejunum?
questions.explanation: Bicarbonate is absorbed indirectly: sodium is absorbed and exchanged with secreted hydrogen ions. These H}^+ ions combine with the HCO}_3^- of the chyme to form carbonic acid, which dissociates into H}_2O and CO}_2 which is eliminated by the lungs.

questions.question: What ion do colon cells secrete when absorbing chloride?
questions.explanation: The epithelial cells of the ileum and large intestine have a chloride-bicarbonate exchanger in the brush border membrane. This process facilitates the absorption of Cl}^- ions while secreting alkaline HCO}_3^- to help neutralize the acid products formed by the bacterial flora in the large intestine.

questions.question: What is the mechanism of cholera diarrhea?
questions.explanation: Cholera toxin stimulates excessive formation of cAMP in crypt cells, opening an enormous number of chloride channels. This causes rapid secretion of Cl}^- and secondarily Na}^+ ions, generating an osmotic flow of water from the blood into the intestinal lumen resulting in diarrhea.

questions.question: What greatly stimulates intestinal calcium absorption?
questions.explanation: The active absorption of calcium ions, which occurs mainly in the duodenum, is finely controlled. Parathyroid hormone activates vitamin D and the latter is the factor that directly greatly stimulates the calcium transport mechanism through the intestinal epithelium to meet daily needs.

questions.question: How are monovalent ions mainly absorbed in the intestine?
questions.explanation: In general, monovalent ions, such as sodium (Na}^+) and chloride (Cl}^-), are absorbed very easily and in very large quantities through the intestinal mucosa, thus satisfying the body's high daily demands for these electrolytes.

questions.question: In what form are most carbohydrates absorbed?
questions.explanation: Virtually all carbohydrates in the diet are absorbed in the form of monosaccharides, the most abundant being glucose, the end result of the digestion of starches. Only a small fraction is absorbed as disaccharides and larger molecules are virtually not absorbed.

questions.question: Which ion is essential for cotransport of glucose to the enterocyte?
questions.explanation: Glucose absorption is a secondary active transport that depends on the low intracellular sodium concentration. Sodium and glucose bind to the same transporter protein at the brush border, and the flow of sodium down its gradient draws glucose into the cell.

questions.question: What is the absorption mechanism of fructose?
questions.explanation: Unlike glucose and galactose, fructose is absorbed by facilitated diffusion across the epithelial membrane and is not coupled to sodium transport. Once inside the cell, much of it is converted into glucose for subsequent transport to the blood.

questions.question: In what form are digested proteins primarily absorbed?
questions.explanation: After digestion, the vast majority of proteins are absorbed through the luminal membrane of intestinal epithelial cells in the form of dipeptides and tripeptides, in addition to some free amino acids. This transport is also a secondary active cotransport driven by sodium.

questions.question: What is the main 'shuttle' function of bile micelles?
questions.explanation: Bile micelles are crucial for fat absorption. They dissolve monoglycerides and fatty acids in their lipid center and efficiently transport them to the surface of the microvilli, where they diffuse into the epithelial cell, then returning to the chyme for the next cycle.

questions.question: What is the fate of absorbed long-chain fats?
questions.explanation: Within the epithelial cell, long-chain fatty acids and monoglycerides recombine to form new triglycerides. These are packaged into chylomicrons, which are released through the base of the cell to empty into the bloodstream through lymphatic ducts, bypassing the initial portal circulation.

questions.question: Where do short and medium chain fatty acids go?
questions.explanation: Short- and medium-chain fatty acids are more water-soluble and are not converted back to triglycerides within the enterocyte. Therefore, they are absorbed directly and diffuse into the blood capillaries of the villus to be transported through the portal vein to the liver, unlike long-chain ones.

questions.question: What is the main function of the absorptive colon?
questions.explanation: The proximal half of the colon, known as the absorptive colon, has a high capacity for active absorption of sodium and water. This function is crucial in reducing chyme volume and forming semisolid stools, as it recovers most of the remaining water and electrolytes.

questions.question: From what substances does the normal brown color of feces derive?
questions.explanation: The characteristic brown color of feces is due to the presence of stercobilin and urobilin. These substances are end products of the metabolism of bilirubin, a bile pigment, by the action of bacteria present in the large intestine.

questions.question: What alteration occurs if the lower esophageal sphincter does not relax during swallowing?
questions.explanation: Achalasia is the clinical condition where the lower esophageal sphincter, due to injuries to the myenteric plexus, loses its capacity for receptive relaxation, making it difficult for food to pass to the stomach.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of pancreatitis?
questions.explanation: Excessive alcohol consumption is the most common cause of pancreatitis, followed by obstruction of the ampulla of Vater by a gallstone, causing autodigestive activation of enzymes.

questions.question: Which pair of irritating substances damage the gastric mucosal barrier?
questions.explanation: Alcohol and acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin) are the substances mentioned that most frequently cause injuries by breaking down the protective barrier of the gastric mucosa.

questions.question: What causes gastric atrophy due to loss of secretions?
questions.explanation: Achlorhydria means that the stomach has stopped secreting hydrochloric acid and is diagnosed when the pH of gastric secretions does not decrease below 6.5.

questions.question: What percentage of people with peptic ulcer have H. pylori bacteria?
questions.explanation: At least 75 percent of people with peptic ulcer suffer from chronic infection in the terminal portions of the stomach and duodenum by the H. pylori bacteria.

questions.question: What is the name of the protein complex necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12?
questions.explanation: Intrinsic factor is a glycoprotein secreted by the parietal cells of the stomach that combines with vitamin B12 to protect it and allow its absorption in the terminal ileum.

questions.question: Where are peptic ulcers most frequently located?
questions.explanation: The most frequent location of peptic ulcers corresponds to the first centimeters after the pylorus, in the duodenum, due to exposure to gastric juice.

questions.question: What is an effect of cholera toxin on the intestine?
questions.explanation: Cholera toxin directly stimulates excessive secretion of electrolytes and fluid by the crypts of Lieberkühn, resulting in massive and life-threatening diarrhea.

questions.question: What is steatorrhea in the context of sprue?
questions.explanation: Steatorrhea refers to excess fat in the stool, a sign of fat malabsorption that occurs in the early stages of sprue, despite proper digestion.

questions.question: What is the cause of constipation called megacolon?
questions.explanation: One cause of megacolon (Hirschsprung's disease) is the deficiency or complete absence of nerve cells in the myenteric plexus of a segment of the sigmoid colon, preventing peristalsis.

questions.question: What reflex persists in defecation paralysis due to upper spinal cord injury?
questions.explanation: When the spinal cord is injured between the conus medullaris and the brain, the voluntary portion is blocked, but the basic spinal defecation reflex, initiated by the passage of feces into the rectum, remains intact.

questions.question: What prevents normal swallowing in myasthenia gravis?
questions.explanation: In diseases such as myasthenia gravis or botulism, impaired neuromuscular transmission prevents normal swallowing by paralyzing the muscles essential to the swallowing mechanism.

questions.question: What condition frequently accompanies gastric atrophy and achlorhydria?
questions.explanation: Pernicious anemia is associated with gastric atrophy and achlorhydria because the absence of intrinsic factor, produced by the same cells that secrete acid, prevents the absorption of vitamin B12.

questions.question: What term describes the upward peristaltic movement before vomiting?
questions.explanation: Antiperistalsis is a movement that precedes vomiting and consists of peristaltic waves directed toward the upper part of the digestive tract, propelling intestinal contents toward the stomach.

questions.question: What hormone is released by acid in the intestine to neutralize gastric juices?
questions.explanation: The presence of acid in the small intestine triggers the release of secretin, a hormone that travels to the pancreas to stimulate rapid secretion of pancreatic juice, rich in sodium bicarbonate.

questions.question: What is the most common bacteria that causes peptic ulcer?
questions.explanation: Chronic infection by the Helicobacter pylori bacteria is the main cause of peptic ulcer, since it breaks the mucosal barrier and stimulates the secretion of gastric acids.

questions.question: What predisposing factor for ulcers is associated with nerve stimulation?
questions.explanation: Tobacco is a factor that predisposes to ulcers, probably because it increases the nervous stimulation of the secretory glands of the stomach, increasing the production of gastric juice.

questions.question: What is used in modern ulcer treatment to suppress acid secretion?
questions.explanation: An acid secretion suppressing drug such as ranitidine, which is an antihistamine agent that blocks the stimulatory effect of histamine on the H2 receptors of the gastric glands, is very useful.

questions.question: What can cause bone demineralization in severe sprue?
questions.explanation: In severe cases of sprue, calcium malabsorption leads to osteomalacia, which is the demineralization of bones due to the lack of this important element for their structure.

questions.question: What disease is due to the toxic effects of gluten in certain cereals?
questions.explanation: Non-tropical sprue, also known as celiac disease in children or gluten enteropathy, is due to the toxic effects of gluten, causing the destruction of the enterocytes of the small intestine.
